titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to The Women's Sports Foundation Records
1950-2019 (bulk, 1974-2018)
MS 3199
titlestmt.author: Margaret Dalton
titlestmt.sponsor: The processing of the Women's Sports Foundation records was made possible by the generous support of the Women's Sports Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-09-05 11:05:37 -0400.

physdesc.extent: in 645 record cartons and 1 flat box

did.abstract: The Women's Sports Foundation was established in 1974 by Billie Jean King to advance the lives of women and girls through sport and activity. The WSF serves as a source of information on women's and girls' sports and a national advocate for gender equality in sports by conducting and publishing research, providing grants to athletes and to sports and community programs, and holding events and conferences. The WSF records document the administrative history of the WSF, from its founding in 1974 to the 2010s. Records include meeting minutes and records of the Board of Trustees, staff files, research files, correspondence, publications, digital files, and collected reference files on girls' and women's sports. Subjects and topics of records include Title IX, equity in adolescent and college sports, athlete advocacy, and administrative and operational functions of the WSF over time. Material dates from 1950-2018, with bulk dates 1974-2018. Portions of the collection are not yet processed and are restricted, as noted in the finding aid.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Women's Sports Foundation was established in 1974 by Billie Jean King to advance the lives of women and girls through sport and activity. The Foundation was first established in San Francisco and supported by individual donations, corporate contributions, and fundraising events. Athletes Donna de Varona, Micki King, Joan Joyce, Wyomia Tus, Sheila Young, Jane Blalock, Paula Sperber, and Mary Jo Peppler were involved in the foundational discussions and early years of the Foundation. For the first two years, the main programs of the Foundation were to act as a central source of information and referral on women's sports, to assist girls' and women's groups in introducing sports programs, the sponsorship of a scholarship for girls' sports camps, and the coordination of seminars and clinics on sports and physical fitness.

In 1976 the first executive director Eva Auchincloss was appointed, and an Advisory Board composed of female athletes and individuals from sports-related fields was formed to set the goals and programs of the organization. It was decided that the WSF would become the national collective voice of women in sports and would work with and through sport and general interest organizations, would devise programs and activities that would help popularize sports and physical fitness for women, would provide a network for women in sports, and would provide a central source of information on women's sports. In 1977 the Foundation established its first grant programs and distributed its first official newsletter. In 1979 Donna de Varona became the first elected Foundation president.

Throughout the early 1980s, the Foundation initiated additional programs, grants, and research projects, including the International Women's Sports Hall of Fame launched in 1980, toll-free information phone line in 1981, internship program in 1982, first Travel & Training Fund grants awarded in 1984, and High School All-Star program in 1985. In 1983 the Foundation, along with the United States Olympic Committee, sponsored the New Agenda Conference, at which more than 500 of the most influential people in sports, education, and government gathered in Washington, DC to address issues of concern to women in sports. In 1985 the proposal for the Aspire Higher campaign to raise three million dollars for the Foundation was created, a Coaches Advisory Roundtable (CAR) was established, and the Foundation conducted its first research study, "The Miller Lite Report on Women in Sports."

In 1986 the WSF relocated to New York City and hired Deborah Slaner Larkin as the second executive director. In 1987 the first National Girls and Women in Sports Day (NGWSD) was held, thanks in part to the Foundation and to Senators Bill Bradley, Ted Kennedy, Bob Packwood, and Ted Stevens and Congresswomen Olympia Snowe and Claudine Schnieder. In 1990 Sudafed joined with the Foundation as the first corporate national supporter, enabling the Foundation to expand staff and programs.

In 1992 Donna Lopiano, former Athletic Director of Women Athletics at the University of Texas came on board as the new executive director. Lopiano developed the Community Awards and Grants program, later renamed the Community Action Program. In 1993 the Foundation moved its headquarters to Nassau County, New York (Eisenhower Park). In 1994 the Athletes' Speaker Service, later renamed the WSF Athlete Ambassador Program, was launched to raise the profile of female athletes and to educate and inspire the public. In 1996 the WSF launched its first website and a weekly email newsletter. In 1997 WSF published the Gender Equity Report Card, an exhaustive survey of athletic opportunities in higher education. In 1998 the Foundation was granted official United Nations Consultative status to the Economic and Social Council. In 2000 the Foundation was awarded the International Olympic Committee's first Women and Sport Award for the Americas. In 2001 the WSF launched the GoGirlGo! curriculum and educational campaign. Throughout 2003 the WSF helped to lead a 12-month campaign with a coalition of more than 100 organizations to engineer grassroots demonstrations in seven cities to oppose the administration's attempts to dismantle Title IX.

In 2008 the Billie Jean King International Women's Sports Center opened in New York City inside the Sports Museum of America. The Museum subsequently closed in 2009. From 2010 to 2014 the Foundation partnered with University of Michigan's School of Kinesiology and its Institute for Research and Women and Gender on the establishment and work of the Sport, Health and Activity Research and Policy (SHARP) Center for Women and Girls. In 2013 the International Olympic Committee selected the Foundation's GoGirlGo! Curriculum as a model for global youth sports programs. In 2004 the GoGirlGo! Education curriculum received a gold National Health Information Award from the Health Information Resource Center.

In 2014 the WSF and espnW co-founded Sports 4 Life, a program to address the racial disparities in access to youth sports opportunities for girls of color. In 2015 the WSF hosted its first Athlete Leadership Connection, an annual event connecting top industry leaders with professional and collegiate female athletes. In 2016 the WSF held its first "Candid Conversations" series to provide champion and college athletes with skills to advance their post-competition careers and held the 30th annual National Girls and Women in Sports Day (NGWSD). In 2020 WSF established The Equity Project, an initiative designed to close the gaps in equitable access and opportunities in sports and to achieve true gender equality.
As of 2021, the mission of the Foundation states, "We are the ally, advocate and catalyst for tomorrow's leaders. We exist to enable girls and women to reach their potential in sport and life."

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. Portions of the collection are restricted, as noted in more detail at the series level.
Materials are stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff. Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282. Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as The Women's Sports Foundation Records, MS 3199, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series I-V were processed by Project Archivist Margaret Dalton in 2021. Digital files from those series were processed by Digital Archivist Margo Padilla. Series VI-IX are currently unprocessed.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related artifacts and objects are held by the New-York Historical Society Museum. Inquiries about these objects can be directed to the Museum at: nyhscollections@nyhistory.org.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Women's Sports Foundation records document the administrative history of the WSF, from its founding in 1974 to the 2010s. Records include meeting minutes and records of the Board of Trustees, staff files, research files, correspondence, digital files, publications, and collected reference files on girls' and women's sports. Records are organized by the originating administrative body, staff member, department, and material type. A discrete group of records labeled as the "WSF Archives" has been maintained and contains the core historical documentation and reference files for the WSF. Subjects and topics of records include Title IX, equity in adolescent and college sports, athlete advocacy, and administrative and operational functions of the WSF over time. Material dates from 1950-2018, with bulk dates 1974-2018.

did.unittitle: Series I. Women's Sports Foundation archives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I includes two groups of files originally stored in the WSF office in vertical filing cabinets labeled "WSF Archives" and "WSF Publications." These files were maintained by WSF staff as the core historical documentation and internal reference files for the organization. The "WSF Archives," or chronological files, includes early descriptions of the organization, annual reports, scholarship guides, coach and parent handbooks, reports and studies, event documents, and clippings. The publication archive includes WSF-produced official newsletters and magazines documenting WSF activities, priorities, and changes over time. Material in this series dates from the creation of WSF in 1974 to 2018.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in two subseries:
Subseries I.A. Chronological files
Subseries I.B. Publications archive

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries I.A includes files originally stored in the WSF office in vertical filing cabinets labeled "WSF Archives." This group of material was maintained by staff as the core historical documentation of the organization. Files provide insight into the programming, structure, and goals of the Foundation over time. The earliest material includes the Foundation's "Statement of Purpose," newsletters, and member and subscriber surveys. Additional document types include the Foundation's newsletters, annual reports, annual scholarship guides, coach and parent guides, reports and studies, and newspaper clippings. WSF programs and events, particularly the WSF Annual Summit, New York Awards Dinner (NYAD), National Girls and Women in Sports Day (NGWSD), and GoGirlGo! events, are documented over time in event programs and planning materials. Files date from 1974 to 2018.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically and maintained in original order from the WSF office. At the end of the chronological run, as well as dispersed throughout the files, several individual folders appear out of chronological order. This potential mis-filing of folders has been maintained as the materials arrived.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original folder titles have been retained. In the instance that a folder was stored inside a hanging file labeled with a separate additional title, this title has been expressed before a colon in the folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

The newsletter includes information on legislation regarding women's sports, conferences and workshops on sports, job opportunities, personal updates on Associates, and referrals to additional sources on women's sports. 1982 file also includes one issue of the WSF Corporate Report, sent to executives of corporations, advertising agencies, and public relations firms that are involved in women's sports and sponsorship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains WSF staff records from various individuals and offices, including Executive Directors Eva Auchincloss, Deborah Slaner Anderson, and Donna Lopiano, as well as Dr. Marjorie Snyder and from the Chief Financial Officer office. Records include correspondence, reports, research and subject files, meeting notes and minutes, and publications. The records document the leadership, operations, finances, programming, and publications of the WSF. Records date from 1974-2014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

Subseries III.A. Executive Director Eva Auchincloss records

Subseries III.D. Marjorie Snyder records
Subseries III.E. Chief Financial Officer records

did.unittitle: Subseries III.A. Executive Director Eva Auchincloss records

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eva Auchincloss was the founding Executive Director of the WSF and was responsible for implementing most of the fundraising and educational programs of the Foundation. Before her appointment as Executive Director in January 1976, she served as the Associate Publisher of womenSports magazine from 1974. Upon appointment, Auchincloss recruited the Advisory Board of the WSF, composed of athlete representatives and representatives from a variety of sports-related fields. Achievements during her tenure included: establishing the New York Awards Dinner as a fundraising event and showcase, spearheading and planning The New Agenda conference held in 1983, and implementing educational programs, particularly the toll-free information and referral line, publication of camp scholarship and athletic scholarship guides, and the High School All-Star awards program. Her term as Executive Director ended in 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.A contains records of Eva Auchincloss, the first Executive Director of the WSF, who served as Executive Director from 1976-1986. Records include documents describing WSF history, research files, correspondence, Board meeting minutes and reports, publications, and subject files. Records date from 1983-1986.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

Subseries III.B. Executive Director Deborah Slaner Anderson records

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Deborah Slaner Anderson was the WSF Executive Director from 1986-1991. Anderson took over the direction of the Foundation upon the move from San Francisco to New York. During her tenure, the Foundation successfully raised $3 million through the two-year "Aspire Higher" fundraising campaign. Anderson doubled the revenues from the annual awards dinner and quadrupled the endowment fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.B contains records of Deborah Slaner Anderson, WSF Executive Director from 1986-1991. Records include correspondence, reports, marketing materials, memos, and a series of files labelled as the "Chronological files" that include correspondence with Trustees, advisors, and donors. Of particular interest are an organizational chart and programs list for the WSF from 1988 and long-range planning documentation from 1989. Records date from 1985-1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.C. Executive Director Donna Lopiano

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Donna Lopiano was the WSF Executive Director from 1992-2002 and the Chief Executive Officer from 2002 until her resignation in 2007. Prior to coming to the WSF, Lopiano was the Athletic Director of Women Athletics at the University of Texas. At the WSF, Lopiano developed the Community Awards and Grants program, secured funds that enabled the WSF to award more than $14 million in cash grants and free education curricula, and expanded the WSF endowment to $4 million.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.C contains records of Donna Lopiano, Executive Director from 1992-2002 and Chief Executive Officer from 2002-2007. Records include correspondence with Trustees, advisors, and donors from Lopiano, minutes and reports from the Board of Trustees, Advisory Board, Executive Committees, and various Ad Hoc Committees, and speeches. Records date 1992-2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Marjorie Snyder had previously held various positions at the WSF, including Chief Program & Planning Officer, Senior Director of Research & Programs, and Interim co-CEO on two occasions. While serving the WSF, Dr. Snyder directed the advocacy, education, research and planning efforts of the Foundation, co-authored research reports, developed the GoGirlGo! Project, and served as Foundation spokesperson and speaker at national and international conferences. Dr. Snyder is also largely credited with collecting and maintaining the archival records of the WSF within their offices. As of 2021, Dr. Snyder is the Senior Research Advisor at the WSF.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.D contains records of Dr. Marjorie Snyder, who has worked for and with the WSF in various capacities from 1987. Records include correspondence, publicity and marketing materials, PSAs (public service announcements), program proposals and files, calendars, publications, event programs, and a file of WSF publications, including scholarship guides, research reports, and educational pamphlets. Records date from 1988-2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.B contains files related to the gender equity advocacy work of the WSF, particularly the advocacy for Title IX legislation and protections. Documentation of Title IX advocacy includes case files, hearing and testimony transcripts, budget files, position papers, research reports, publications, newsclippings, and correspondence. Case files include those in which WSF's Donna Lopiano served as an expert witness. The files document state and Federal legislation related to gender equity in sport and education over time and research conducted measuring the effects of Title IX and related legislation. The New Agenda conference held in 1983 is also documented. Materials date from 1971-2006.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are arranged in original order, starting with Title IX legislation files removed from hanging folders in WSF office filing cabinets, followed by files removed from storage boxes of the WSF offices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.C contains files documenting the research projects and publications of WSF. Documents include research planning files, proposals, correspondence, contracts, research reports and publications from non-WSF organizations, WSF research reports and additional publications, and conference materials. Research topics include the health of girls and women, college sports participation and funding, effects of sport on childhood and adolescent development, and Title IX in sport. Material dates from 1973-2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.D contains records of the WSF education department and records generated for education programs, events, and publications. Publications include resource guides for student athletes, parents, coaches, and scholarship guides for students entering college programs. Programs and recurring events documented in the files include National Girls and Women in Sports Day, the GoGirlGo! program (known as the BJK project in initial years), and It Takes a Team. Individual conferences attended by WSF staff are also documented in conference materials, notes, and presentations. Records date from 1983-2012.

Subseries IV.E. Events and development records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.E contains records documenting WSF events and development functions, including recurring and annual award programs, annual dinners, and auctions, and outreach events. Particular recurring events documented in the files include the annual conference, the Annual Salute to Women in Sports (often referred to as the "New York Annual Dinner" or "Awards Dinner" as abbreviated as "NYAD"), the Annual Summit, and National Girls and Women in Sports Day (often abbreviated as "NGWSD"). Record types include correspondence, itineraries, meeting minutes and agendas, event programs, press clippings, and contracts. The records reflect changes in scale and focus of recurring events, processes of planning events, participation and attendance of athletes, and perception and awareness of the work of the WSF. Particular development records include a group of undated donor files. There is also a group of binders holding copies of WSF newsletters and publications at the end of this subseries. Material dates from 1976-2014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are arranged as received from the donor.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records related to the recurring National Girls and Women in Sports Day event are located in subseries IV.D. Education records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.F contains records pertaining to the Community Impact functions of WSF, including grant-making programs, student athlete programs, and professional athlete programs. Particular programs and services documented include the Coaches Advisory Roundtable (often shortened to CAR), athlete Travel and Training Grants, GoGirlGo grants, the Athlete Ambassador Program, the Athlete's Speaker Service, and various awards granted by WSF. Record types include grantee applications and winner records, correspondence, budget forms, publicity materials, and program guides, called "playbooks," for staff. This subseries also contains an alphabetical run of subject files for athletes and coaches considered for and inducted into the International Women's Hall of Fame. Records date from 1983-2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are arranged as received from the donor.

Subseries IV.G. Marketing and partnerships records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.G contains marketing, publicity, and partnership records. Materials include news clippings and articles, correspondence, branding campaign planning materials, public relations playbooks, playbooks for particular marketing campaigns, files with partnership records and contracts for particular brands and organizations, and supporter mailings. This subseries also includes a group of literature and marketing samples produced by other organizations and collected by WSF. The organizations collected include non-profits, businesses, and athletic programs. Sample publication types include annual reports, mailings, brochures, and informational guides. Material dates from 1984-2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are arranged as received from the donor.

Subseries IV.H. Operations and finance records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IV.H contains records of WSF operations and finance. Content includes documentation of building maintenance and real estate, leases, contracts for services, funding, and events, trademark filings, and financial and tax statements. This subseries also contains records pertaning to the Nassau County WSF Museum project and the National Sports Museum. Records date from 1978-2014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are arranged as received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V contains photographs of WSF events, staff, and publicity material, as well as an "athlete survey" alphabetical file of athlete photographs, and an alphabetical file of sports photographs. Events include WSF meetings, conferences, sports clinics, press conferences, and fundraising dinners and galas. Formats include prints, negatives, and slides. Material dates from 1951-2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in 4 subseries:
Subseries V.A. Athlete surveys
Subseries V.B. Events and staff
Subseries V.C. Sports alphabetical file
Subseries V.D. Slide carousels

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries V.A contains an alphabetical file of photographs organized by athlete last name and labelled in the WSF offices as "athlete surveys." Contents of each folder include photographs and completed athlete surveys. Not all folders contain both photographs and surveys. Material dates from 1951-2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by athlete last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries V.B contains photographs from WSF events and of WSF staff. Events include WSF meetings, conferences, sports clinics, press conferences, and fundraising dinners and galas. Particular recurring events documented include the Annual Salute to Women in Sports, often referred to as "NYAD" or "New York Annual Dinner" or "New York Awards Dinner," and National Girls and Women in Sports Day (NGWSD). Material dates from 1973-2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are arranged as received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Suberies V.C contains an alphabetical file of photographs organized by sport name. The alphabetical files are followed by a group of additional folders containing youth sports photographs and additional subjects. Formats include photographs and slides. Material is largely undated, but circa 1980-2000.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are arranged in order as received from the donor. A run of files in alphabetical order by sport is followed by a group of additional folders containing youth sports photographs and additional subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries V.D contains boxed slide carousel trays, slides, and presentation materials created and used by the WSF. The carousels are labelled by presentation or event title and have been retained in their original boxes. The title of each item has been transcribed from the box. Presentation materials include a variety of formats, including the slides, printed presentation scripts and notes, and audio cassettes, and varies for each presentation. Presentations date circa 1980-1995.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by order of receipt from the donor.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series VI has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI is currently unprocessed. Based on legacy inventories, this series contains nearly complete runs of womenSports (1974-1984), Women's Sports Magazine (1979-1984), and Women's Sports and Fitness (1984-1998). WSF is the official repository of Women's Sports and Fitness and its precursors. There is significant duplication of magazine issues. Also included are miscellaneous issues of Sports Illustrated, Sports Illustrated for Women, The International Swimmer, and Olympic Review. Material dates from 1974-2000.

did.unittitle: Series VII. Audiovisual and digital formats [RESTRICTED/ unprocessed]

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series VII has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII is currently unprocessed. This series contains audiovisual and digital format materials created by and collected by the WSF. According to legacy inventories, content includes athlete interviews, publicity and marketing material, and events footage. Formats include Betacam, U-matic, floppy disc, VHS, DVCPRO, CD, DVD, and zip disc. Materials date from approximately 1975-2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series VIII has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VIII is currently unprocessed. This series contains artifacts, objects, and memorabilia created by and collected by WSF that have not been selected for accession into the New-York Historical Society Museum. This series may also contain large-format printed material, such as posters. The materials and objects date from approximately 1975-2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series IX has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IX. is currently unprocessed. This series contains the WSF's library collection of books and reference files originally collected and maintained in the WSF offices for staff and research use. Reference files are comprised primarily of an alphabetical reference file containing sports news article clippings. The WSF library contains books on women's sports and recreation. Material dates from 1957 to 2004.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in two subseries:
Subseries IX.A. Reference files and inventories
Subseries IX.B. WSF library books

did.unittitle: Subseries IX.A. Reference files and inventories [RESTRICTED/ unprocessed]

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series IX.A has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IX.A. is currently unprocessed. According to legacy inventories, this series contains a group of reference files organized alphabetically by sport that contain reference material about individual sports, including athletes, history, organizations, and teams, mostly as news article clippings. The subseries also contain video inventories and research reports compiled by the WSF for reference use of their collections. Material dates from 1975 to 2004.

did.unittitle: Subseries IX.B. WSF library books [RESTRICTED/ unprocessed]

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series IX.B has not yet been processed and is currently restricted from access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries IX.B. is currently unprocessed. This subseres contains all books from the WSF's library collection, maintained in their offices for reference use and documentation of women's sports. Topics of books include general women's sports, athletes, and recreation. Books date from 1957 to 2007.
